author: Microcredentials Polska
text: 📣 Tylko 15% pracowników w Polsce deklaruje posiadanie kompetencji, które mogą zapewnić im awans w ciągu najbliższych trzech lat. Aż 90% nie dostrzega znaczących inwestycji ze strony pracodawców w rozwój ich umiejętności – wynika z raportu ADP Research Institute „People at Work 2025”. Jednocześnie, według danych Główny Urząd Statystyczny, zaledwie 20% dorosłych Polaków uczestniczy w szkoleniach poza formalnym systemem edukacji.👁️ Tymczasem World Economic Forum prognozuje, że do 2030 roku powstanie 170 mln nowych miejsc pracy – głównie za sprawą transformacji technologicznej i zielonej gospodarki. To oznacza radykalne zmiany w wymaganiach zawodowych. Dotyczyło to będzie 39% kluczowych umiejętności. 👉 W odpowiedzi na zmiany na rynku pracy Instytut Badań Edukacyjnych - Państwowy Instytut Badawczy (IBE- PIB) realizuje od 2023 roku pilotażowy projekt mikropoświadczeń, współfinansowany z Funduszy Europejskich. Powstają one zgodnie z opracowanymi przez IBE PIB standardami i wydawane są za pomocą aplikacji Odznaka+.❗️ O tym, dlaczego mikropoświadczenia mogą zmienić sytuację tysięcy pracowników w Polsce, stając się ich przepustką do awansu przeczytacie w naszym najnowszym wpisie na blogu microcredentials.pl 📌 Link w komentarzu 👇____________📣 Only 15% of employees in Poland report having the skills that could ensure a promotion within the next three years.As many as 90% don’t recognise significant investments from employers in developing their skills, according to the report from ADP Research Institute “People at Work 2025”. At the same time, according to data from Główny Urząd Statystyczny (GUS), only 20% of Polish adults participate in training outside of the formal education system.👁️ Meanwhile, World Economic Forum predicts that by 2030, 170 million new jobs will be created – mainly due to technological transformation and the green economy. This will mean radical changes in job requirements, impacting 39% of key skills.👉 In response to changes in the labour market, Instytut Badań Edukacyjnych - Państwowy Instytut Badawczy (IBE-PIB) has been running a pilot microcredentials project since 2023, co-financed by European Funds. These microcredentials are created according to standards developed by IBE-PIB and issued through the Odznaka+ application.❗️ Read our latest blog post on how microcredentials can change the situation for thousands of employees in Poland, becoming their ticket to promotion. 📌 Link in the comments 👇hashtag#mikropoświadczenia hashtag#microcredentials hashtag#FunduszeUE

author: Josiane Dongmo
text: America should  focus on making America great again… What on earth is their business with Capt Ibrahim Traore?🤔I’m genuinely puzzled as to why Burkina Faso has become a discussion point at a U.S. Senate Commission. And even more concerning—how General Langley could go so far as to label Captain Ibrahim Traoré a threat to his people because, allegedly, he’s using the country’s mining resources for “personal protection.”Wait—are we talking about the same Captain Traoré who:✅ Declared free education from nursery to university for all Burkinabè ✅ Is actively investing in agriculture and economic recovery ✅ Is reclaiming territorial control from terrorist groups and working to secure his country's bordersBurkinabè citizens have shielded their president from over 19 assassination attempts. That doesn't sound like a population in distress—it sounds like a people standing with their leader.So, here’s my question: Why does Africa’s business suddenly matter to Western powers... when they’ve shown minimal interest in the continent’s stability unless resources or control are involved?Historically, Africa has minded its own business. I’m beginning to think that has been our greatest crime as people living on earth. We don’t invade. We don’t interfere. We don’t convene commissions to micromanage foreign nations. Africans have mostly just wanted to thrive on their land, raise their families, tend their farms, drink their beer and live in peace.If Africa is now building defenses and manufacturing or buying weapons, it’s not out of aggression—it’s out of necessity. Burkina Faso is simply trying to survive. Like any sovereign nation, it deserves the right to protect its people and its resources.And let me be crystal clear: We do not need another "Libya" situation. Remember how “help” looked in 2011? Libya was promised freedom. Instead, they got chaos, instability, and a broken state. That should never be repeated.Dear America, please:  🛑 Stop weaponizing concern. 🛑 Stop interfering where you’re not invited. 🛑 Focus on your borders, your people, your economy, your “Great again”.Burkina Faso’s people are not asking for rescue. If they ever do, it’s safe to say Western intervention isn’t the first place they’ll turn to. And rightfully so.By the way, If anyone in the comments can name one U.S. intervention in Africa that led to sustainable peace or prosperity—please, do share. I’m listening.hashtag#AfricaFirst hashtag#BurkinaFaso hashtag#CaptainTraore hashtag#AfricanSovereignty hashtag#NoMoreInterference hashtag#WestAfricaRising hashtag#PanAfricanism hashtag#LibyaLesson hashtag#GlobalJustice hashtag#USAfricaPolicy hashtag#DeColoNow hashtag#AfricanVoices hashtag#LetAfricaBreathe hashtag#JosianeSpeaks

author: Dr. Deepessh Divaakaran (Dr. DD)
text: India doesn’t need faculty.It needs academic Superman / Superwomen, trained to survive UGC’s very own Hunger Games.Do everything.Smile while burning out.Or perish without promotion.Welcome to the Faculty Thunderdome.Let the circus begin.Here’s what it takes to wear the UGC-approved Superman cape in 2025:→ Teach long hours a day→ Publish in “(un)known journals” (even if no one reads them)→ File patents (real, fake, who cares?)→ Mentor lost students→ Manage NAAC documents that change every 3 months→ Organize convocations, fests.→ Organize blood donation camps, tech expos. → Organize talent shows.→ Secure funding (from thin air)→ Travel across India (on your own dime) to present papers to empty rooms→ Contribute to NIRF/NBA/NAAC metrics (bonus points if you can game them)→ Sell Seats during Admission→ Visit and sell courses to 12th Std Students of Near by Schools.→ Work minimum 12 hours — because UGC thinks sleep is optional→ Dress like a CEO during NAAC visits→ Go full-on traditional for guest welcomes — with that mandatory fake smile→ Escort NBA peer teams like VIP bodyguards→ Write a book no one will read (Or Buy Fake Authorship, who cares)→ Say “Thank you, sir” with a straight face at every pointless reviewAnd… still find time to innovate like you're at MITAnd if you can't?You're non-performing.No CAS. No promotion.Just shame. And silent suffering.And Ofcourse - BP MedicationBut here’s where it gets truly laughable…NEP 2020 – Section 4.5 says:"No one-size-fits-all for students."👏 Bravo. Lovely. But for faculty?We apply the same-size straightjacket. 🤭 No flexibility. No nuance. No choice.Everyone must teach.Everyone must research.Everyone must hustle.Everyone must publish.Everyone must Perish.And now… some colleges have started dance practice too.Just in case NAAC wants a performance.Dear Intellectuals at UGC,Not all teachers are researchers.Not all researchers are teachers.But you want everyone to be everything.Because… India needs to become Viksit Bharat.At any cost. Even if it means burning out its thinkers.This is your way to bring innovation? 🤦 This isn’t education reform.It’s institutional comedy — with tragic consequences.We’re not building universities.We’re building pressure cookers —And calling them “centres of excellence.”Rubbish.This is a "Centres of exploitation."Academic brilliance?Or academic stupidity?You tell me.Drop your thoughts below —but only if you’re done with lesson plans,exam duty,NBA files,patent drafts,WhatsApp messages from your Dean,and anchoring tomorrow’s blood donation camp.Now a days even colleague who greets you with:“Got Scopus?”Faculty fam — if this post felt like a staffroom rantyou’ve been dying to scream… 🫣 Hit ‘Repost’.Like and Comment.So UGC knows we’re juggling flaming swords while smiling for the NAAC team.

author: Sagar Bahadur
text: I feel fortunate to witness the global higher education landscape from both a macro and micro lens. Across boardrooms, campuses, and policy halls, change is afoot - not always loud, but absolutely real!At Acumen, Part of Sannam S4 Group, we are seeing these shifts through student choices, partner priorities, and on-the-ground actions across geographies. We are not just observing but we are investing in these trends, helping universities future-proof their strategy and footprint.Here are 10 silent shifts that are already shaping the next chapter of global higher education:1. Students care more about jobs than rankingsPrestige is being replaced by practical outcomes. Students are asking: Will this lead to a job I want? Institutions must adapt faster.2. Micro-campuses are the new global playThinking mega-builds? Agile, local micro-campuses offer faster ROI, flexibility, and responsiveness.3. The “third country” student is the new normBorn in one country, schooled in another, and studying in a third! Student mobility is complex. Systems must evolve to support them.4. Enrollment strategy > recruitment targetsThe focus is shifting from getting students in to helping them thrive! Retention, outcomes, and support now define success.5. The Big Four are no longer the only destinationsStudents are choosing emerging hubs like Germany, UAE, Japan, Korea, and India! All this is driven by better visas, career routes, and local relevance.6. Sustainability is a deciding factorToday’s students care deeply about values. Green campuses and climate-conscious curricula now influence enrollment more than we think.7. Reverse TNE is on the riseWestern universities are sending students to Asia and the Middle East for credit-earning immersions, strengthening bilateral ties.8. School-university pipelines are being reinventedK12 partnerships are evolving beyond recruitment! Co-developing curriculum and preparing students more intentionally for higher ed.9. Regional autonomy is unlocking growthOne-size-fits-all is out! Empowered local teams are enabling faster decisions and more relevant strategies in high-growth regions.10. Higher ed as a tool of soft powerEducation is emerging as a powerful diplomatic channel. Student mobility and partnerships now influence global relations.These aren't just trends; they are realities already in motion. And the institutions that move early will shape what comes next.At Acumen, we are embedding these insights into our partnerships, policy engagements, and operations every day. If these shifts reflect what you are seeing too — let’s talk.hashtag#HigherEd hashtag#GlobalEducation hashtag#EdTrends hashtag#TNE hashtag#FutureOfLearning hashtag#AcumenInsights

author: Rémi Président Fondateur AIDE AUX PROFS
text: Après 18 ans sans enseigner, de 2018 à 2024 j'ai fait un retour en classe.J'avais demandé un lycée, puisque agrégé hors-classe, mais j'ai obtenu un collège au public très agité, avec des élèves de 20 nationalités (un environnement culturel intéressant), mais ce collège aurait bien mérité d'être siglé REP: ce fut très "sportif".Je déplore comme Société des agrégés de l’Université que les agrégés n'aient pas plus de priorités pour obtenir un lycée dans le système d'affectation de Education nationale qui reste un système très inégalitaire, irrespectueux du grade et des compétences des personnes. En une carrière de 39 ans mon seul passage en lycée aura été l'année de stage. J'ai eu beau demander un lycée de 1990 à 2001 puis en 2018 à mon retour, je n'ai jamais obtenu satisfaction, même depuis ma réussite à l'agrégation externe en 1996. J'avais contacté mon IA-IPR qui m'avait dit ne rien pouvoir y faire, qu'il me fallait attendre d'avoir "assez de points".Le système de mutation des profs est très mal conçu. Ce fut frustrant d'avoir atteint le niveau de préparation d'une thèse de géographie, d'être agrégé 12e/50, et de devoir rester en collège. J'ai heureusement pu enseigner de 1997 à 2004 à l'université en Facultés de Géographie et de Géologie, comme vacataire. Mais n'ai jamais terminé ma thèse car ce rythme m'a épuisé. Mes secondes carrières hors enseignement pendant 18 ans furent les plus belles années de ma carrière. En 2018 j'avais envie de démissionner mais après 55 ans dans le privé c'est très difficile de retrouver un emploi.De 2018 à 2024 j'ai donc subi des classes chargées, beaucoup d'élèves indisciplinés, des cas problématiques. J'ai pu vérifier que l'éducation nationale n'a pas (plus ?) les moyens d'endiguer la violence scolaire, que le règlement intérieur d'un établissement n'est plus adapté aux excès des élèves actuels, que le soutien apporté aux enseignants mis en difficulté par leurs élèves ou leurs parents reste symbolique.J'ai fait cette nouvelle expérience de l'enseignement car je savais que je pouvais l'écourter à tout moment.En effet, de 2016 à 2023 me furent proposés plusieurs postes de hashtag#cadre en administration intéressants, que j'ai tous refusés pour conserver ma liberté d'expression associative, car la contrepartie eut été de cesser AIDE AUX PROFS.Une contrepartie impensable. Après 55 ans le métier de hashtag#professeur devient éprouvant. Être toujours énergique et en bonne santé face à des élèves dont l'âge reste le même aux niveaux enseignés, est un défi quotidien. Moralité : oui, le métier d'hashtag#enseignant est usant, épuisant après 55 ans. Je l'ai vécu. La génération qui a dû obtenir le hashtag#Master2 devra travailler jusqu'à ses 65 à 70 ans pour obtenir "le taux plein de pension" et ce sera terrible pour eux.Vieillir dans ce métier est un véritable défi, les politiques publiques n'en parlent jamais, et les politiciens continuent d'allonger les carrières.Il y a là tout un chantier de réflexion à mener.

text: China, Kenya upgrade ties amid 'turbulent international situation' China and Kenya announced they had upgraded ties to a "new level" on Thursday during a meeting between President Xi Jinping and Kenyan President William Ruto in hashtag#Beijing, as they both pledged to create an "all-weather" China Africa community.In a joint China-Kenya statement, both leaders said they were "committed to injecting more stability into the world with the certainty of China-Africa solidarity and cooperation".This would provide a backbone to safeguard the "common interests of developing countries", it said, and defend the multilateral system, via "inclusive economic globalisation".The decision to upgrade China-Kenya relations was made "in the face of a turbulent international situation", the Chinese president was quoted as saying in a separate media pool report.Africa is a key focus of Xi's ambitious hashtag#BeltandRoadInitiative, launched in 2013 to extend China's geopolitical and economic influence through global hashtag#infrastructure development.Kenya has been a key hashtag#BRI recipient, and Nairobi has taken a raft of loans from hashtag#China to finance infrastructure hashtag#construction projects that have made China the East African nation's biggest bilateral lender.Among new projects announced by the Kenyan presidency on Thursday, China will invest in the extension of a standard gauge railway to the border with hashtag#Uganda. Completion of the line has stalled since 2019 due to lack of funds.China will also invest in the expansion of a major highway linking the capital hashtag#Nairobi with the Rift Valley city of Nakuru, through a public-private partnership model, it said. Ruto's office did not provide details on the deals, but previous Kenyan government estimates have put their value in the billions of dollars each.Xi and Ruto signed 20 documents together on Thursday, according to a media pool report. These included agreements on science and technology cooperation, vocational education, water resources, ecommerce, intelligent transport systems and the railway sector.Kenya has been struggling with a heavy hashtag#debt load and the accompanying cost of servicing it.Ruto, who took office in September 2022, has promised that his government will not default on its external debt, pledging to cut waste and boost revenue to tackle the challenge.It is Ruto's first state visit to China as president of hashtag#Kenya. author: Dr. CA Narendra Shyamsukha
text: I was born in a small town in Rajasthan, where opportunities were few and awareness was limited. My early education was in Hindi. I had a love for numbers and a quiet determination to do something meaningful with my life.That determination led me to Kolkata in the mid-80s, where I pursued Chartered Accountancy. The language was new to me and the environment was unfamiliar. But my commitment was strong.At 22, I cleared my CA exams and started my practice.For nearly a decade, I built my firm from scratch — one client, one referral, one timely delivery at a time. It was honest work. It gave me success and stability.It also gave me something else — perspective.In the late 90s, I set up a small data entry unit to support my CA firm. I hired fresh commerce graduates and trained them to handle real accounting work. I noticed something unusual: within a few months, many of them were getting better offers. Not because they had degrees,  but because they had gathered the skills.At the same time, I would meet hundreds of young graduates struggling to find jobs. And employers constantly complaining that “good people are hard to find.”The problem was not a lack of talent. It was a lack of preparation.That was my turning point.In 1999, I took a decision most found difficult to understand — I gave up my CA practice and started ICA Edu Skills's first training centre. No business model. No roadmap. Just a strong belief: that if we could train people the right way, we could change their lives.The journey that started with one classroom has now reached over 120 centres.And along the way, whenever we identified a gap, we built a solution for it. When we saw students struggling to get digital and content roles despite degrees, we started IDCM - Institute of Digital & Content Marketing — a dedicated training initiative for digital marketing. That’s always been my way of working. Quietly. Systematically. With a simple belief: if you can see a problem clearly, you can fix it — if you’re willing to build for the long term.And that same belief has led me to this next chapter — bringing India’s talent, systems and execution capabilities to the global stage. Especially for CPA firms who need partners they can trust, not just outsource to.The country has the talent. We have the infrastructure. Now, we’re ready to serve the world — the same way we’ve served India.hashtag#CA hashtag#ICA hashtag#CAPractice hashtag#Journey hashtag#Entrepeneurship hashtag#CAinIndia hashtag#Leadership hashtag#CPA

author: Sivakumar Babuji
text: The dedication and hard work of Maths teacher Abdul Malik, who lives in a small village in the southern state of Kerala, India, has become an example. In the last 20 years, he has never been late to reach school, nor has he taken a single day off. Even today, he goes to school by swimming across the river with the help of a rubber tyre, carrying a bag on his head, so that no child's studies are interrupted. Abdul Malik shared this unique life journey of his in the BBC program Outlook.About his village, he tells that it may be a small and ordinary village, but its biggest feature is the tradition of education here. Education has been given importance here for generations and this is the reason why many teachers reside in this small village.When Abdul Malik was asked why he chose the path of becoming a teacher, his answer was, "Becoming a teacher not only makes us better citizens ourselves, but also gives an opportunity to show the right direction to others. Education is the medium that makes us an ideal for children."The school Malik goes to teach is in a village across the Kadalundi river. If he goes by road, the distance to the school is about seven kilometers, while by river the distance is just one kilometer. This village is surrounded by the river on three sides and there is neither a doctor nor any other teacher here. In such a situation, dedicated teachers like Malik are the light of the future of the children of this village.hashtag#Inspiration hashtag#Motivation hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedIn hashtag#India

author: Jacques Fischer
text: The 3 most powerful words in leadership:Aren't “I did this.” They're “You did this.”What separates excellent leaders from average ones? ↳ It's not their expertise, experience, or education↳ It's their ability to shine the spotlight on othersThe more you give credit away, the better your team will perform. 🔵 How BlueLeaders™ Give Credit:➨ Hunt for Wins: Actively seek situations where team members deliver excellence➨ Amplify Excellence: Turn every success into a story of individual achievement➨ Shine the Spotlight: "Did you see Sarah's analysis? She boosted efficiency by 20%."➨ Broadcast Wins: Celebrate successes in meetings, emails, and with senior leadershipCommon Outcomes:✔️ Strengthened trust and loyalty✔️ Higher engagement and discretionary effort✔️ Sustained high performanceIf you're not actively giving credit away, You’re quietly sabotaging your team’s results.🔴 How RedLeaders Do it:➨ Seize the Spotlight: Tell upper management, “Look at what I accomplished,” even when it was the team’s work.➨ Mix “I” with “We”: Frame successes in first person (“I delivered…”) rather than giving credit to the individual or team.➨ Forget to Mention Names: Announce successes without naming contributors➨ Exclude from Celebration: Don’t invite team members to the celebration partyCommon Problems This Causes:❌ Eroded trust and waning motivation❌ Slipping engagement and effort❌ Departure of top performers❌ Stagnant, mediocre results👉 Giving credit isn’t a skill gap.It’s a mindset shift.Your team's success is your success. author: Nozibele Qamngana
text: When I was 17, I secured a full scholarship that promised to change my life. To the funders, it was an easy sell: “Invest in this child, she’ll be the first in her family to graduate.” The theory behind this pitch seemed sound. In practice, the reality was more complex.Three years later, only 30% of my cohort earned their qualification. A significant portion didn’t even make it past the first year. So, what happened? Were these students ungrateful? Were they not taking advantage of the opportunities given to them? And what didn’t we get right?The truth is, there were many layers to this situation. Yes, the students needed the scholarship, but they also needed far more than just academic support. They needed psychosocial support.Many of us were uprooted from our homes, some from child-headed households, leaving behind siblings who depended on us. Part of the allowance we received was sent back home to help our families. I distinctly remember one of my peers, who was constantly distracted by thoughts of a sick sibling back home, despite being in class.These were the realities of where we came from.Years later, I’m heartened to see that the conversation around education has evolved. What started as a question of “How many students can we fund with X amount of money?” has shifted to “What would be the real impact of investing in this program?” or "How best can we support these students?"It’s a welcomed mindset shift that recognizes the deeper, multifaceted support children need to truly succeed.Investing in education is no longer just about funding a seat in a classroom. It’s about nurturing the whole person, emotionally, mentally, and socially, to help them thrive, both in their studies and in life.

author: Valentine Boyev
text: Case study: $600K raised, fueled by clarity and design.Our branding + UX turned vision into investor-ready.✦ The Client.A startup that employs AI tools to help reduce stress and improve the performance of students and educators.✦ The Challenge.➡️ Students need help when and where it's unavailable.➡️ Teachers are unable to provide students with individual attention on a consistent basis, especially in hybrid or remote learning environments.➡️ The product needed to feel "human," accessible, and incredibly intelligent without overwhelming the user.✦ What we did.➡️ Brand discovery & naming.We helped rebrand DigestAI into Acton Street, Inc., which was inspired by the founder's experience living next to students.➡️ Logo concept.We designed a simple logo and took cues from a bike crank (a thoughtful suggestion of urgency, movement, education, and progressive learning).➡️ Web design.We created bold visuals with purpose, laying the foundation for a simple, confident black-and-white web design that subtly echoed the AI service provider.➡️ Micro-animations.Menu transitions, hover effects on cards, and deliberate movements made the web interface feel alive, and helpful.➡️ Webflow development.A built-from-scratch web design that offered a great feel and pixel-perfect build. Mobile-priority and custom interactions that avoided design bloat.✦ The Result.→ $600K raised in funding.→ 2 new investors on board.→ A product experience that truly matches the innovation and humanity behind the brand.Want to create a web presence that wins trust and attracts?Let’s build it—strategically, beautifully, and with purpose.🔔 Follow Valentine Boyev for more updates!

author: Reliance Industries Limited
text: Media Release - “This is a very special game — you can be the inspiration for thousands of children.” – Mrs. Nita M. Ambani urges MI players ahead of ESA Day~ Mumbai Indians to celebrate hashtag#ESADay on April 27 at the Wankhede with 19,000 kids ~Mumbai, 25th April 2025: Mumbai Indians’ game against Lucknow Super Giants, scheduled for Sunday, 27th April at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai, will be dedicated to the Education and Sports for All (ESA) initiative championed by Mrs. Nita M. Ambani. The annual ESA game is one of the biggest highlights of the IPL season every year for the Mumbai Indians, with thousands of spirited children from NGOs across the city lighting up the stadium with their infectious energy and dreams.Ahead of the upcoming ESA game, speaking to the Mumbai Indians team, Mrs. Nita M. Ambani said, “People who have been with Mumbai Indians know our next game is very special, we have underprivileged children coming, and the energy is really special. So please, put up your best show for them. They wait for years in line to get to come and see one match.”She also recalled a moving experience from a past ESA Day: “I was sitting in the stands with all of them, and this girl wasn’t eating much. She was picking on her food. I asked her why, and she said, ‘I’m saving it for my brother, because he’s never tasted cake in his life.’ These are the things that we want to support.  We want to inspire these kids, that in spite of coming from different backgrounds, you can achieve wonders.”Urging the players to make the day extra special, she added: “This is a very special game for me and for all of you who have been a part of this for many years. You can be the inspiration for these children and show them that they can be whatever they dream to be.”ESA, a flagship initiative of Reliance Foundation (the CSR arm of Reliance Industries Limited) in collaboration with Mumbai Indians, was launched in 2010 with the vision of making education and sports accessible to children from all backgrounds. Each year, MI’s one IPL match is designated as the ESA game, bringing to life the initiative’s mission to empower young minds, inspire ambition, and instill the joy of sports and learning.About ESA: https://lnkd.in/gnDeQggzHere are some glimpses of Mrs. Ambani in the stands with the kids from last year: https://lnkd.in/eP69hjpTHere is the link of Mrs. Ambani talking about ESA Day to the players:https://lnkd.in/eRJ6gHrtFollow Mumbai Indians on:Website – https://lnkd.in/guuhGApA Instagram – https://lnkd.in/gCykYy-7 YouTube – https://lnkd.in/gNj2kUza

author: Anastasia Ttofis 🟡🔴🔵🟢
text: I spend £1,800 a month on my mentor. That’s just under £21,600 a year. And that’s just my 1-2-1 Mentoring.I go to retreats deeeep breathwork, shadow work, crazy triggering retreats costing anything between £1-£2k a pop.Plus somatic teacher trainings - I’ve spent about £8k in the last 6 month on becoming a qualified somatic teacher. Why? Anyone who is serious about making big business moves needs to also invest big money into themselves.There’s very few business models where you can invest £0 and get £1m out (don’t listen to the no money in property gurus)And it’s not even about the money.➡️Wanna be the person who stands out, embodies everything they say, the best person they can be for themselves, their friends, their team….➡️Trusts their inner authority, does not need external validation, is compassionate and a good listener, understand their emotions, is really ok with being completetly and utterly themselves ….➡️You want real happiness, freedom, success, joy… The list goes on…There is NO WAY ❌you’re doing all of that without a mentor. You might read it and think “feck off Anastasia, I am all of those things all by myself” That’s ok, you can think that, but it’s just not true. We can only take ourselves so far, and if we wanna be better, for ourselves, those around us, our business, then we need a mentor.Without one, you’ll get stuck.Stuck in our own BS, ego, trauma, emotional awareness or skill level.And then probably decline (as some others around us excel)Would I rather spend that money on a butlins adult weekender? Absolutely 😏Or maybe even a cheeky trip to Mexico ☀️But investing in myself is the greatest gift I can give to me 🫶And it’s the only thing that can never be taken away from me.The holidays end, the fancy car get’s repossessed 😜 but I will ALWAYS have the education and investment I’ve given to myself.Whether it’s £1k a month, £100 a month, or £10 a month.Invest in yourself.Business is hard, and being a better version of you makes it a little easier.

author: Sonja Wehsely
text: Only 2% of girls – but 24% of boys – choose a technical school after lower secondary school.When I first came across this contrast in reports from the Austrian Institute for Advanced Studies (IHS), it made me pause. And the pattern continues: while 1 in 3 male graduates of technical colleges (HTL) go on to pursue a STEM degree, only 15% of female graduates do the same.Despite years of effort, the gender gap in STEM remains wide — not because girls lack talent or ambition, but because the system still doesn’t fully support them.The IHS study reveals a sobering reality: Girls in Austria are significantly less likely to complete a STEM education, less likely to enter a STEM profession — and more likely to leave it early. Why?Because of persistent stereotypes.Because of a lack of visible role models.Because of work cultures that don’t yet support part-time roles or family life.That’s why initiatives like Daughters’ Day are so important. When girls feel seen, encouraged, and welcomed into spaces they might never have imagined for themselves — real change begins.🌟 Let’s keep supporting programs that don’t just introduce girls to technology, but help reimagine what a future in STEM can look like: inclusive, creative, and full of opportunity.Kudos to our Austrian colleagues for creating safe spaces where girls can explore their potential!hashtag#GirlsDay hashtag#Töchtertag hashtag#STEM hashtag#Diversity hashtag#Inclusion hashtag#WomenInSTEM hashtag#SiemensHealthineers

author: Prof. Santosh Kumar
text: Prof. Krishnaswamy Kasturirangan (1940–2025)India mourns the passing of Prof. Krishnaswamy Kasturirangan, a towering figure in science and education, who breathed his last at the age of 85. A distinguished space scientist and visionary policymaker, Prof. Kasturirangan served as the Chairman of ISRO, where he steered India’s space programme into a new era with landmark missions including the development of the PSLV and GSLV. His contributions were not confined to space—he played a pivotal role as Chairperson of the Drafting Committee for the National Education Policy 2020, shaping the future of Indian education with a progressive, holistic, and inclusive vision. As a member of the NEP Draft Committee on Liberal Education under Prof. Kasturirangan’s leadership, I was deeply inspired by his clarity of vision, humility, and unwavering commitment to transformative, learner-centric education.Prof. Kasturirangan’s illustrious career includes the tenures of becoming the chancellor of the Jawaharlal Nehru University and chairman of the Karnataka Knowledge Commission. He also served as a member of Rajya Sabha and the Planning Commission of India.A recipient of the Padma Shri, Padma Bhushan, and Padma Vibhushan, Prof. Kasturirangan was revered for his intellect, integrity, and lifelong commitment to national development. His legacy will continue to inspire generations of scientists, educators, and policymakers. India has lost a guiding light. May his soul rest in peace.(pic. courtesy: Wikipedia)

author: Jessica Götberg
text: Nytt möte med Martin på Mälardalens universitet idag. Rektor berättade om senaste mötet med MDUs styrelse där styrelsen har diskuterat vision och mål för MDU. En ny karta ska sättas där missionen är att arbeta för Education for global citizenship. Mission, vision och mål ska vara en karta för alla medarbetare på MDU och ligga till grund för all utbildning och forskning. Rektor menar att den nya kartan visar att MDU ska gå från detaljstyrning till tillitbaserad ramstyrning. Vidare diskuterades den hashtag#orange omställningen och att det kommer att bli två fakulteter med dekaner som har till uppgift att forma en organisation och arbete inom respektive fakultet för att arbeta efter den karta som nu ritas. Universitetsdirektören berättade om hur Verksamhetsstödet går in i en ny organisation från 1 juni där fokus på arbetet måste ligga på att verka för stöd för kvalitet i utbildning och forskning. De nya åtta avdelningarna inom verksamhetsstödet ska nu arbeta för att skapa behovsanpassat samlat stöd för kvalitet i utbildning och forskning. Samarbete mellan den kollegiala strukturen och verksamhetsstödet lyftes som en viktig framgångsfaktor. Rektor lyfte också studentrekrytering som viktigt och centralt i arbetet framåt. Här har alla medarbetare på MDU ett arbete att göra. Vi behöver vakna upp för att skapa attraktiva utbildningar där studenterna är stolta ambassadörer för MDU.

author: Pamela (Theophilus) Gardner
text: hashtag#collaboration hashtag#communication hashtag#accuracy In response to irritated listeners of a BBC radio 4 programme yesterday (24/4/25), reported as: Guest "Chickpeas have as much protein as meat". Presenter: "Sold".   Oops! Presenter was misled. Inference from guest was an equality in protein terms, whereas biological value (BV) is greater from an animal source – related to deficiency of some amino acids in plant sources. Important note: Deficiency does not necessarily mean absent. It is the relative proportions in animal sources that are better suited to the functioning of the human body. However, the BV from plant sources can come closer to the BV100 of animal sources by combining pulse and cereal proteins in the same meal.(BV of protein is distinct from the bioavailability of micronutrients from different food sources.)

author: Susan Charlesworth
text: She quietly changed hundreds of lives, including mine.Last night I went to the retirement do of my friend and former colleague, Kathie Bowden.We worked together at the UK Space Agency during Tim Peake’s Principia mission. I was focused on education; Kathie was championing skills and careers for university students and early-career professionals.She founded the SPIN programme (Space Placements in Industry) which has helped hundreds of young people gain experience in the space sector.She’s one of those people who makes things happen behind the scenes. No fuss. No ego. Just steady, purposeful impact.She is also a mentor to me. A listening ear, a calm presence, someone who believed in growing the next generation and made time to support others along the way.Last night’s celebration was full of people whose careers have been shaped by her work.It reminded me how powerful one person can be, and how important it is to create opportunities, even when no one’s watching.Here’s to the Kathies of the world.And to being that person for someone else.---Image of some of the UK Space Agency’s Education and Skills team, past and present. author: Raj Sanghvi
text: Maharashtra's GDP is now more than UAE's GDP! $543 billion versus $528 billion. For a single Indian state to outpace a global economic hub is no small feat and deserves recognition. But before we start celebrating, it's important to look deeper. Maharashtra’s GDP per capita stands at just $4,370, while the UAE's is a staggering $46,518. That’s a 10x gap, highlighting that overall GDP doesn’t automatically mean prosperity for the people. What really matters is how that wealth is distributed and whether it translates into better jobs, healthcare, education, and infrastructure. Maharashtra has the scale, now it needs to convert that into quality of life for its citizens. True progress will come not from topping GDP charts, but from lifting every segment of society along the way.Photo Credit - INDmoney

She is going on secondment to support the communications of our Cardiff University / Prifysgol Caerdydd Research Service. It’s a better opportunity for her - she is someone that deserves to fly and fly high! Immensely intelligent and extremely competent, she has brought exceptional levels of professionalism to the team, juggling the huge variety of work that we do with quality and care and brilliant customer service. She was instrumental in propelling our work with local schools and Cardiff Council’s ‘Passport to the City’ to encourage children to consider University and business which we valued so much! I haven’t written a blog about her, not because she doesn’t deserve one, but because we’re not losing her completely, as we are with John Parry-Jones (His last day too! Argh!) and quite frankly writing it might send me over the edge! Thank you for all that you have done for us Angharad and John. We’re so grateful and we will miss you tremendously!

author: Ankita Ray
text: “I am not afraid of storms, for I am learning how to sail my ship.” — Louisa May AlcottIn September 2024, I took a bold step to bring back the classroom after nearly 13 years — this time not just to learn, but to evolve.I'm thrilled to share that I’ve joined the “Transitioning into Leadership: A Programme for Women Executives” by IIM Calcutta. It’s a 1+ year certification designed to shape strategic thinking, build influence, and foster inclusive leadership among women leaders — and I’m proud to be a part of it. It's been a good 7 months and we are almost mid-way through the programme and with each session, I discover a new learning.My professional journey began as an instructional designer. Today, I lead a dynamic Education team in an automation product company — a space where continuous learning is as critical as delivering outcomes.This program has reignited my learner mindset, but with a twist — now it's all about application, reflection, and rising as a purpose-driven woman leader.Balancing work and studies isn’t easy, but when both align with the purpose, the effort becomes empowering. Here’s to unlearning, relearning, and becoming a better version of myself — one thoughtful step at a time.📚💼✨hashtag#WorkandStudies hashtag#LeadershipJourney hashtag#WomenInLeadership hashtag#IIMCalcutta hashtag#LifelongLearning hashtag#WomenWhoLead hashtag#LearningAndDevelopment hashtag#LeadershipGrowth hashtag#LeadByExample hashtag#GrowthMindset

text: 🎓 Diplômée de mon Bachelor en Communication Digitale à l’ISEFAC. Hier a eu lieu la cérémonie de remise des diplômes de la promo 2024 du groupe IONIS Education Group. Une étape importante pour moi à 27 ans, mais surtout un symbole : celui d’une reconversion réussie.Il y a encore quelques années, je vivais à l’étranger, à la recherche de moi-même, un peu (beaucoup) perdue face à l’avenir. Aujourd’hui, je suis fière d’avoir osé reprendre mes études, de m’être réorientée, et d’avoir (enfin) trouvé une voie qui me passionne. Ce parcours me confirme une chose : il n’est jamais trop tard pour se réinventer. Merci à l’ISEFAC, aux intervenants, et à toutes les personnes qui m’ont soutenue dans cette aventure. author: Neha Nagar
text: He invested ₹40 lakhs in a foreign degree… and now he can’t afford rent.A Reddit post is going viral—and it’s a wake-up call for every aspiring international student.An Indian student took a ₹40 lakh education loan to study abroad, hoping for a high-paying job.But after graduation, He was not able to get an overseas job.Now back in India, he earns ₹75,000/month—but pays ₹66,000/month in EMIs.That leaves just ₹9,000/month to survive.This isn’t a one-off case.It’s a growing pattern.Even with STEM degrees, many international graduates are struggling. Why?-Tighter visa norms-Companies preferring local hires-Global slowdown in tech hiring- Skyrocketing cost of international educationA foreign degree no longer guarantees a foreign job.And without a job abroad, repaying a foreign loan from Indian salaries becomes financially unsustainable.Now he has to face: -Delayed life goals—no savings, no investments, no home planning-Constant mental stress—every month is a financial balancing act-Years lost in recovery—when peers are investing, he's just survivingSo, before investing ₹40–50 lakhs in education, students and parents must analyse:-What is the post-study work visa landscape?-What is the average placement rate and salary in that country?-Is the degree aligned with high-demand skills?-What is the break-even period for ROI?Higher education should be a calculated decision, not a blind leap of faith.hashtag#studyabroad hashtag#educationloan

text: 💡 Reimagining Education: What if we majored in questions, not subjects?For over a century, education has been built around static disciplines: law, history, engineering, medicine.Fixed subjects. Fixed paths. author: Yogita Daulatani
text: As today marks completion of 12 years of my professional journey, working across large-scale public programs — from water to housing, education to skilling — I’ve finally decided to do something truly radical...Post on LinkedIn !Yes, I’ve been one of the quiet ones here.More comfortable navigating Government corridors than social media scrolls.More fluent in implementation frameworks than engagement algorithms.But over time — working across ministries, rural hamlets, slums, and policy thinkfests — I’ve come to realize something: ◾ Our stories from the field matter. ◾The messy, meaningful meanderings through government systems teach us     a lot. ◾And those of us in the business of development need to share more — with honesty and humility.Lately, I’ve also been learning the art of storytelling in a very different setting — trying to craft tales that hold the attention of my two-year-old 😊So I figured LinkedIn might just be the perfect practice pad — to tell stories from my trysts with the Indian development sector.From piloting policy initiatives for millions, to figuring out how a single water tap can change a village’s rhythm — it’s been a ride through the alleys of Indian governance, with a pit stop or two in multilateral strategy decks.More soon — but for now, I’m just glad to have finally shown up here.👋🏼Hello, LinkedIn. Let’s talk development !

author: Manar🌟 Hamid
text: 4 أسئلة مهمة عشان تفهم إذا إدارة المشاريع مناسبة ليك❓ 1.هل لازم أغير مجالي عشان أتعلم إدارة المشاريع؟ 🎯أبدًا! إدارة المشاريع ما شرط تكون تغيير مهني – هي مجال تكميلي (Discipline)، مش بديل.يعني:🧠 تقدر تكون مهندس، طبيب، مبرمج، مصمم، أو إداري... وتتعلم إدارة المشاريع عشان:تنفّذ شغلك بشكل أفضلتنظم وقتكوتقود فرق أو مبادرات داخل مجالك📌 إدارة المشاريع بتساعدك تكبّر تأثيرك داخل تخصصك، بدون ما تغيّر مهنتك الأساسية.💼 أمثلة عملية:المبرمج العندو خلفية في إدارة المشاريع ممكن يقود فريق تطوير.المصمم الفاهم إدارة الوقت والموارد ممكن يستلم مشروع إبداعي كامل.المهندس البعرف يخطط ويتابع ويحل مشاكل ممكن يتطور بسهولة لمنسق أو مدير مشروع.✅ إدارة المشاريع مهارة مهنية تكميلية – بترفع من قيمتك، وتفتح ليك فرص جديدة في نفس مجالك.(زي ما ذكر Hussam Mandil 🔗 https://lnkd.in/duzYbHr5) 2. هل أي شخص ممكن يكون مدير مشروع؟🎯ما بالضرورة. زي ما في ناس شغوفة بالتنفيذ والتخصص، في ناس غرضها القيادة والتخطيط – ودي كلها أدوار مهمة ومكملة لبعضها.🧱 في فرق كبير بين:✔ الزول العندو مهارات تنفيذ (زي التصميم، البرمجة، البناء...)✔ والزول العندو كفاءات قيادية (يخطط، يتابع، يحل مشاكل، يدير فريق...)إدارة المشاريع بتجمع بين الاثنين – بتديك نظرة واسعة تساعدك تشوف الصورة الكبيرة، مش بس التفاصيل اليومية.3. 🧠 طيب شنو الفرق بين المهارات والكفاءات؟Skills = تنفيذ مهمة محددةCompetencies = مزيج من: 🔹 المعرفة 🔹 المهارات 🔹 السلوكوده العمق الحقيقي اللي الـ PMP بتركّز عليه. (زي ما شرح أ. Hussam Mandil : https://lnkd.in/duzYbHr5)🤝 وكمان الفرق بين Soft Skills vs Hard Skills الموجود في الملف ادناه🧩 PMP بتقيس مزيج من الاثنين – عشان تتأكد إنك قادر تنجح كقائد مشروع، مش بس منفّذ.4. 📚 طيب لو اتحصلت على الشهادة؟ هل معناها إنك خلاص بقيت مدير مشروع ناجح؟لا طبعًا. الشهادة ما بتخليك مدير مشروع ناجح تلقائيًا.زي أي شهادة مهنية محترمة، شهادة PMP بتقدّم ليك:✅ معرفة مبنية على أفضل الممارسات العالمية✅ محتوى مطوّر بخبرات سنين من معهد PMI✅ امتحان دقيق لقياس مستواك✅ ربط بين المعرفة النظرية والخبرة العمليةلكن النجاح العملي يتطلب كمان:🛠 خبرة حقيقية في بيئة مشاريع📈 استمرارية في التعلم والتطوير🌍 متابعة للتغيرات في السوق والمجال🤝 التزام بميثاق الأخلاقيات (Code of Ethics) الخاص بالمعهد🏅 القيمة الحقيقية للشهادة:مش بس امتحان ونجاح! ✅ لازم خبرة عملية موثقة ✅ التزام بمعايير مهنية عالمية ✅ توقّع بمستوى عالي من التفكير والمسؤولية ✅ تطوير مستمر (Continuing Education)🎓 في النهاية:بغض النظر عن طريقتك في توسيع فهمك في إدارة المشاريع، الرؤية الواضحة هي الأساس. إنت الشخص الوحيد القادر تجاوب على سؤال: "هل أنا مناسب أكون مدير مشاريع؟" والإجابة بتجي من مقدراتك، توجّهك، وطموحك المهني.ولو اخترت تمشي في مسار الشهادات، فـ PMP شهادة مهنية عالمية معروفة — لكنها ما مناسبة لكل الناس.والمهم تعرف:✅ الشهادة جزء من الصورة، لكن من دون تطبيق باقي الأركان (الخبرة، المهارات، السلوك، التطوير المستمر)، ما حتكون مدير مشاريع ناجح.PMP مناسبة للناس العندها هدف واضح، وعندها الرغبة تمشي خطوات حقيقية نحو القيادة، المسؤولية، والتأثير في بيئة مشاريع.hashtag#إدارة_المشاريع hashtag#PMP_بالعربي hashtag#مشاريع_السودان hashtag#نصائح_مهنية hashtag#ProjectManagement

author: Milja Saari
text: Tänään Professoriliitto'n kevätseminaarissa keskustellaan tiedeperusteista kasvusta ja hyvinvoinnista. Research Council of Finland | Suomen Akatemia'n  Vaikuttavuuden ja tiedepolitiikan yksikön johtaja Floora Ruokonen pitää alustuksen Strategiset valinnat ja tiede kasvun mahdollistajana. Kun valmistelimme Flooran ja kollegoiden kanssa alustusta, kävimme mielenkiintoisia keskusteluita tieteen ja kasvun suhteesta - niin synergioista kuin ristiriidoistakin. Odotan innolla, millaisia keskusteluita tänään käydään tieteestä ja miten, mistä ja millaista kasvua Suomi tarvitsee. Jotta pystymme ratkomaan yhteiskuntamme suuria haasteita, vuoropuhelua ja yhteisiä toimia tarvitaan - ja tieteellä ja tutkijoilla on paljon annettavaa. Seminaaria voi seurata suorana verkkolähetyksenä klo 12.15 alkaen.
